section.name: CELL NEUROBIOLOGY: Molecular and Cellular Neurobiology

comments:
This course covers cellular physiology of neurons and excitable cells, molecular
neurobiology, and development. Topics include: action potential generation; synaptic
transmission; molecular and physiological studies of ion channels; second messengers;
simple neural circuits; synaptic plasticity; learning and memory; and neural development.
Students described this class as informative and very interesting. One student
described it as “by far one of the most valuable and educational courses that I have taken
in my four years at Penn.”
Students often found it difficult to follow the professors who would often digress in the
middle of class and seemingly lose their place. That being said, students found that each
professor had their own style of teaching, which seemed to add to some confusion.
Students felt that this class was difficult, and one student described it as being
“more difficult than it needed to be.” Some described the tests as being “tricky” and
often found it difficult to keep up with the information on exams due to the changing
professors. This course is recommended for majors.

section.name: CELL NEUROBIOLOGY: Molecular and Cellular Neurobiology

comments:
Molecular and Cellular Neurobiology is a course that covers the cellular physiology
of neurons and excitable cells, molecular neurobiology and development. Topics covered
include: action potential generation, synaptic transmission, molecular and physiological
studies of ion channels, second messengers, simple neural circuits, synaptic plasticity,
learning and memory, and neural development.
Overall, students really enjoyed this course, describing it as “great,” “interesting,”
“comprehensive” and “a good overview” of the topic. Students reported learning a lot
from the course, but some noted that it could be “disorganized” at times. Some students
really enjoyed having four professors teach the course, but others found it “a bit
distracting” and said the course lacked cohesion. This made it difficult for students to
adjust to the professors’ different teaching styles. One student reported enjoying this
course’s integration of biology and physics, which made it “intellectually exciting and
fulfilling,” and another liked that the course had an “emphasis on concepts rather than
detail.”
Students were mixed in their opinions about Dr. Abel. While some found him to be
a good teacher, the majority described him as a “poor lecturer,” and several noted that he
“often got off topic.” One student noted that he “tends to teach based only on past
experiments that may be beyond the depth of an undergraduate;” a few others described
him as “unclear.”
Prerequisites for this course are Biology 101 and 102, or Biology 121. Physics
102 or 151 is also strongly recommended. Most students described this course as
“difficult” overall and exams as “tricky.” Exams reportedly required “more thought and
problem-solving skills” than knowledge. Homework was not mandatory, but many found
it useful in preparing for exams. Readings were described as “supplementary” rather than
necessary. A few commented on the quick pace of the course. One noted that it is a “good
supplement to the BBB major,” and others recommended it to Biology majors. There is
also a three-hour lab with a fee in addition to the three hours of lecture.

section.name: CELL NEUROBIOLOGY: Molecular and Cellular Neurobiology

comments:
Molecular and Cellular Neurobiology is a course that covers the cellular physiology
of neurons and excitable cells, molecular neurobiology and development. Topics covered
include: action potential generation, synaptic transmission, molecular and physiological
studies of ion channels, second messengers, simple neural circuits, synaptic plasticity,
learning and memory, and neural development.
Overall, students really enjoyed this course, describing it as “great,” “interesting,”
“comprehensive” and “a good overview” of the topic. Students reported learning a lot
from the course, but some noted that it could be “disorganized” at times. Some students
really enjoyed having four professors teach the course, but others found it “a bit
distracting” and said the course lacked cohesion. This made it difficult for students to
adjust to the professors’ different teaching styles. One student reported enjoying this
course’s integration of biology and physics, which made it “intellectually exciting and
fulfilling,” and another liked that the course had an “emphasis on concepts rather than
detail.”
Dr. Schmidt got mixed reviews from students. While some students found him to
be an “effective communicator” of the core concepts and a “very clear instructor,” others
disagreed, describing him as “somewhat unclear,” ill-prepared for lectures, and noted that
he often goes off topic during lectures. One student described Dr. Schmidt as having a
“serious demeanor, though kindhearted.” His notes, charts, and figures made difficult
topics “clear and understandable,” though.
Prerequisites for this course are Biology 101 and 102, or Biology 121. Physics
102 or 151 is also strongly recommended. Most students described this course as
“difficult” overall and exams as “tricky.” Exams reportedly required “more thought and
problem-solving skills” than knowledge. Homework was not mandatory, but many found
it useful in preparing for exams. Readings were described as “supplementary” rather than
necessary. A few commented on the quick pace of the course. One noted that it is a “good
supplement to the BBB major,” and others recommended it to Biology majors. There is
also a three-hour lab with a fee in addition to the three hours of lecture.
